subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] On PALM
msgSnippet: The Up form of Ado (Zuck s names again) is introduced at the top of page 15 in the QM. In the jerome font, they are typed with a and u . Ted
messageBody:
The 'Up' form of 'Ado' (Zuck's names again) is introduced at the top
of page 15 in the QM. In the jerome font, they are typed with 'a' and
'u'.

Ted


On Nov 20, 2007 9:16 PM, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
> >
> >
> > Regarding 'Ado+Roar', I agree with the solution of using
> > ligature/separated letters to indicate unstressed/stressed
> > distinctions. I believe you suggested this yourself earlier, Paul.
> > Another stylistic choice could be to switch to the alternate
> > letter-form 'Up' in words such as 'arrest'.
>
> What does the character Up look like? (Some days the web page secondshaw
> displays right, and other days it doesn't.) If you could just tell me
> what keys to punch and what font to use for these alternate letters,
> that would help me.
>
>
> >
> > I've been meaning to bring up the way that the SQUARE, NEAR, and CURE
> > sets are handled in your News program. A quick look in the dictionary
> > highlights the problem:
> >
> > SQUARE S K W EH1 R
> > NEAR N IH1 R
> > CURE K Y UH1 R
> >
> > Earlier John linked the choices we make for these sets together:
> >
> > Set Choice 1 Choice 2
> > SQUARE Et + Roe Eight + Roe
> > NEAR It + Roe Eat + Roe
> > CURE Foot + Roe Ooze + Roe
>
> I'm not sure about John's original argument. It seemed good at the time,
> but Read's proposal in the QS manual seems what I am looking for:
>
> merry Ed Roar (er) no ligature DRESS + R lexical set
> Mary Age Roar (Er) Air SQUARE lexical set
> marry Ash Roar (Ar) no ligature NEAR lexical set
> mire Ice Roar (Fr) no ligature PRICE + R lexical set
> mar Ah Roar (yR) Are START lexical set
> more Awl Roar (Yr) Or NORTH/FORCE lexical set
> mere If Roar (ir) Ear NEAR Lexical set
> murder Ado Roar (ar) Earth NURSE lexical set
>
> These combinations seem conventional and workable for the short run, if
> not the long haul.
>
>
> >
> > Later he came up with a convincing argument for Choice 2. I think your
> > program should look for R following these vowels and modify them as
> > needed. I haven't looked yet to see how many words would be converted
> > incorrectly by such a simple rule, but if it turns out to be a large
> > number, then I guess we're stuck with Choice 1.
>
> Yes, that will be the next step. First I am going to simply paste my
> ligatures into some spots in the Private Unicode area. Then I will
> regenerate the CMU dictionary, replacing the ligatures for the
> combinations. It will be tricky working with words like "arrest." I
> might have to change these words when I come to them. Last, I will see
> if the group approves of the new spots for the Unicode characters, and
> if so, make these spots semi-official. The proposal for our own Unicode
> plane is another matter.
>
>
> >
> > Of course, if we merge 'Foot' and 'Ooze' then the last one goes away.
> > I'd be fine with that. But I'm still contemplating the larger change
> > that Anthony has proposed...
> >
>
> Anthony also suggests we should create a solution to deal with Ado,
> which is already overburdened. So he seems to be trying to work things
> out in a very helpful way. I probably should not have brought up getting
> rid of Wool or Ooze. We don't really need to, so why create more work
> for ourselves and get rid of a somewhat useful feature right now?
>
> Paul
>
>
